head.title: Spare the Praise, Help the Child

hedline.hl1: Spare the Praise, Help the Child

abstract.p: Jason Rosenfeld letter on Oct 18 article on new theory by educators and child psychologists that less praise parents give their children helps boost self-esteem; says elders should express lively interest or note child's hard work; says children should learn how to praise themselves

block.p: Re ''New Advice for Parents: Saying 'That's Great!' May Not Be'' (news article, Oct. 18):

At age 32, I still think to myself: ''My parents and teachers routinely said I was intelligent, so why can't I understand more quickly? Why can't I act more decisively? Why aren't I making more money?''
Re ''New Advice for Parents: Saying 'That's Great!' May Not Be'' (news article, Oct. 18):

At age 32, I still think to myself: ''My parents and teachers routinely said I was intelligent, so why can't I understand more quickly? Why can't I act more decisively? Why aren't I making more money?''
I agree that elders should not always give direct praise for a child's successes, but should instead express a lively interest or note the child's hard work.
Children should learn how to praise themselves, because parents and teachers aren't around forever. JASON ROSENFELD Brooklyn, Oct. 18, 2000
